instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
This board was liquid damaged. Board was cleaned in the Crest ultrasonic. 
Everything on the board works, in fact the battery will charge, and it will run off the battery, but the battery is not being detected. 
I have tried a different top case with a known good battery and a different interposer board. Same issue remains. 

Can you guys help me troubleshoot this? 
Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
My bet is it's missing "the screw." There is a screw holding the battery into the computer.

If not that, my bet is on SMC data line.

1) Put red probe on ground, black probe on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> with no power applied to the board, and give me the measurement. 
2) Put red probe on ground, black probe on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> with no power applied to the board, and give me the measurement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
Here are the diode mode measurements you requested: 

pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> is 0.338
pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is a short to ground (0.002) to be exact

it's not missing "the screw" and I did try using a known good interposer board between the battery connector and the mlb.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
I'm going to replace <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> and let you know what happens. 
Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: It's not <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>. That measurement you gave me shows a short to ground. <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> does not have a path to ground. something on that line has a path to ground and is causing this. It can be <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, it can be <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>, it can be some solder blob somewhere. Start by removing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and seeing if it goes away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: I removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and the short on <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is still there. What should I do next? Is removing <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> the next step?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: I'd inject 2v on the line to see what gets hot to confirm, but yeah, most likely <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: Pretty sure your SMC is dead. Use new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and SMC from donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: Hi had the same issu with the same board. I changed several time the SMC, same problem. Then I realised a pin of the UM 29 503 battery connector (inter the board and the battery) was fold down. I set up it right, then it work. Somebody touch the MacBook in a wrong way before me.
